docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey is ahead of schedule in meeting several public health goals, particularly in reducing teenage pregnancies and decreasing tobacco and alcohol use by teenagers, according to a report issued last week by the State Department of Health and Senior Services. Eddy Bresnitz, the state epidemiologist, said improvement was needed in several areas, including the rate of obesity and the percentage of children without health insurance. That percentage increased from 10.2 percent in 1999 to 11.1 percent in 2003, the most recent year for which figures were available.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Health Improvements Reported

docs.lead_paragraph: A law firm that spent decades winning lawsuits against huge corporations is now in the cross hairs of a government investigation.

headline.sub: The Government Takes Aim at a Class-Action Powerhouse ;

docs.snippet: A law firm that spent decades winning lawsuits against huge corporations is now in the cross hairs of a government investigation.

byline.original: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN and JONATHAN D. GLATER

docs.lead_paragraph: Four months before enrollment begins, the Bush administration has started a cross-country campaign to sell its most significant domestic policy initiative, the new Medicare drug benefit. But it is encountering skepticism from some consumers, whose participation is critical to the program's success. In a stop here, four top Bush administration officials, including the surgeon general of the United States, said the drug benefit would be a boon to retirees, worth $1,300 a year to a typical recipient and much more to those with low incomes.

headline.main: OFFICIALS' PITCH FOR DRUG PLAN MEETS SKEPTICS

docs.snippet: Opinion polls suggest that many people have not heard about the new Medicare drug benefit or do not understand it.

docs.lead_paragraph: The chasm between the job that pays the bills and the lifework that provides personal satisfaction never seems as wide as when one's bliss depends on securing a place at the table set by the music industry. This gap -- actually, more the size of the Grand Canyon -- is explored in ''Hustle & Flow,'' a film opening this week. The film describes the unlikely aspirations of a bottom-rung Memphis pimp named DJay who, after an epiphany in a church, decides that becoming a rapper and expressing his ''flow'' will turn his life around. But since this is an equal-opportunity chasm, several people -- DJay; Key, a producer who records boring legal proceedings and has all but left his own commercial musical dreams behind; and Shelby, who creates rhythm tracks when he isn't stocking vending machines -- must all keep their day jobs.

headline.main: A Paycheck in Their Pockets, But a Song in Their Hearts

docs.snippet: The challenge of choosing a career in the entertainment industry is beating the odds to make a living.

docs.lead_paragraph: JIM SINEGAL, the chief executive of Costco Wholesale, the nation's fifth-largest retailer, had all the enthusiasm of an 8-year-old in a candy store as he tore open the container of one of his favorite new products: granola snack mix. ''You got to try this; it's delicious,'' he said. ''And just $9.99 for 38 ounces.'' Some 60 feet away, inside Costco's cavernous warehouse store here in the company's hometown, Mr. Sinegal became positively exuberant about the 87-inch-long Natuzzi brown leather sofas. ''This is just $799.99,'' he said. ''It's terrific quality. Most other places you'd have to pay $1,500, even $2,000.''
docs.snippet: Costco Wholesale, the nation's fifth-largest retailer, pays its workers 42 percent more on average than its closest rival, Sam's Club.

docs.lead_paragraph: The paper-pushing method of paying medical bills, which has long been fairly resistant to the electronic age, is about to be challenged as new payment options like health savings accounts and prepaid medical cards gain wider acceptance in the workplace. Beyond their practical aspects, these products -- and health savings accounts in particular -- represent a philosophical shift toward consumer-directed health care, with people taking a more active role in supervising their medical treatments and benefits.

headline.main: Personal Business; Health Care at the Swipe of a Card

docs.snippet: The paper-pushing method of paying medical bills is about to be challenged by health savings accounts and prepaid medical cards.

docs.lead_paragraph: For 8, 10, sometimes 14 hours a day, they wipe apple juice off sticky chins, chide wobbly toddlers lurching toward a staircase, snuggle dusty 2-year-olds as they make their way from the playground. It bewildered some rescue workers on Thursday to realize that the tiny child buried beneath the rubble of a building that had just collapsed on Broadway, the one Brunilda Tirado had been calling for desperately -- ''My baby! My baby!'' -- was not Ms. Tirado's child at all. But scores of her fellow nannies, who spend their days caring for other people's children, were surprised by the surprise.

headline.main: City Nannies Say They, Too, Can Be Mother Lions

docs.snippet: Moments like those on Thursday, when a nanny tried to shield a child from a collapsing building, underscore the iron bond that can develop between nanny and child.

multimedia.credit: Nannies and parents may have ambivalent relationships, but an iron bond can develop between nanny and child.
multimedia.caption: The Nanny-Child Bond

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Nannies and parents may have ambivalent relationships, but an iron bond can develop between nanny and child.

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Matthew Sweeney, Janon Fisher and Ann Farmer contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday about settlements to be paid to doctors by health insurers involved in a class-action suit omitted a label. The figures represented millions of dollars. A corrected chart appears today, on Page C2.
